Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: Steven J. Streitfeld "SJS"
Reviews.Content: I should say right from the outset, the most important factor in buying a digital camera for me is the camera's zoom capability.  Several years ago, I began my digital camera collection with a cheap Samsung (S630), followed the year after with the Panasonic Lumix DMC FZ-8 (432mm zoom)  and the next year with the FZ-18 (504mm).  It seems each year, camera companies try to outdo one another with the biggest zoom for the buck.  Several weeks ago, I bought this camera with a mind-numbing 840mm zoom.  Don't be surprised if the 1000 mm zoom comes out next year.  Surprisingly, for a camera with this kind of capability, it is light as a feather and differtentiates itself from the other ultrazooms out there by eliminating the Electronic View Finder completely in favor of a 3" screen monitor (I suspect this omission may cost them sales).  The instruction manual can be downloaded from the Olympus web site.  The camera's software can be downloaded by connecting the camera to your computer (make sure your memory card has been removed to download software)  What also differentiates it from the others out there is that you can edit the still pictures you have taken using the special effects function from reducing red eye, shadow adjustment, adding/reducting color saturation, and cropping.  Some of these functions were available in my Samsung S630, but in none of the more expensive Lumix models.  With most digitals, if you want to edit your pictures, you would have to download them to your computer and use the camera's editing software or Photoshop.  By using Panorama function you can take up to 3 shots manually or automatically  and the camera's computer "stitches" them together into one panoramic wide angle shot. quite a technological achievement.  Also differentiating this camera from its main competitor, the Fuji HS 10, a rather affordable price tag of $349 vs. $499 for the Fuji.  The HS10 also has a smaller manual 720mm zoom and uses 4 AA batteries as its power source, which I consider a disadvantage in taking motion pictures.  The SP 800uz has the capability of adjusting the focal distance during film recording in some modes, not always available in cameras of this class.  Unlike the Lumix cameras, there is no hood lens included to take shots in bright sunlight, a slight disadvantage.  There is no thread on the barrel for attaching wide angle or telephoto lenses, but with an 840 mm telephoto lens, why would you need one?  The camera comes with cables to connect to your computer and your HDTV to playback still and movie pictures in 720i high definition.  A rechargeable lithium battery pack is offered instead of the Alkaline or NiMH rechargeable batteries in Olympus' previous models.  If you take a lot of motion pictures, alkaline or rechargeable NiMH batteries must be replaced or recharged at more frequent intervals than most Lithium battery packs, or you could continue to invest in 12 packs of disposable alkaline cells.  The rating for the included standard Lithium battery pack is 900 mAh.  Imported batteries with a rating of 1400 mAh are available from 3rd party suppliers.  A higher Mah rating means you get more usage between charges since the battery has a higher storage capacity, similar to having a larger gas tank on your car.  Battery capacity is important if you use your camera frequently or take motion pictures which drains the battery...and your memory card.  Another factor to consider is the camera's 2GB internal memory, making it possible to store many pictures without the use of a memory card.  The camera has an app to transfer the pictures taken from the camera's internal memory to the memory card.  The camera accepts SDHC cards up to 8GB, an important consideration if you take a lot of motion pictures.  There are several shooting modes available and the camera has a small user-friendly internal manual to explain each mode and what flash, ISO, aperture, white balance settings are available for each mode, making taking pictures almost foolproof. There is a manual pop up flash for low light conditions.  For shots taken with the digital zoom you should use a tripod to avoid camera shake at the far ranges, a problem endemic to a lot of ultrazoom models, not just this particular model or manufacturer.  This is a great camera if you take sports pictures from the nosebleed seats, go on whale watches frequently, or want to take unobtrusive shots of your subjects from a distance.  With an impressive ISO of up to 3200 sensitivity (unfortunately, the higher the ISO, the higher the distortion and graininess when enlarged for prints) you can also take excellent shots of moving subjects.  I rate this camera highly.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera for amateur and professional
Reviews.Author: Gary Vengley
Reviews.Content: There are so many models out there and this camera is really a good fit for those who want to just take good looking photos and videos without having to go to school to learn how to operate this camera.  Once you get past the prelimanary stages of locating all of the buttons and what they do it is pretty easy to perform the functions and it will do just about anything you want it to.  It's versatility is what sells this camera as it doubles as a camera and video so you aren't lugging around equipment when you go out on your vacations or just to the park.  The 30x zoom makes life so easy when you are on trips and can't get close to the subject matter.  We take a lot of cruises so when you are on the balcony and want to take a picture of something that is far away...no problem at all.  The Panarama setting is so easy to operate that it adds another dimension to taking pictures in exotic locations.  The digital age makes it so easy to take and discard photos that you like and don't like and you end up with the 'perfect picture' that you wanted.  14 megapixels will ensure you never have to worry about quality of reproducing photos and since we don't reproduce any photo over an 8x10 we know it will come out perfect.A 4 gb chip is more than you need and gives you enough room for photos and videos.  Anything more than this chip is overkill and who wants to store that many photos on a chip without D/L to a storage area?The only drawback I see on this camera is the setup where you really need to read the instructions so that you don't end up erasing the memory of the camera instructions before you insert the chip.  Our camera did not come with the instruction booklet so I had to go to the website to D/L it and then go step by step from the instructions to set it up.  Very important that you follow this or you will erase the onboard camera memory...that's a bad thing.Camera setupSet the camera date and time, time zoneand display language automatically; installthe camera instruction manual and PCsoftware (ib).Do not insert SD/SDHC memory cardsbefore the camera setup.Do not format the internal memory until thecamera setup is complete. Doing so willerase the camera instruction manual andthe PC software (ib) data that are stored onthe internal memory.Check that your computer meets thefollowing system requirements:Windows XP (SP2 or later)/Windows Vista/Windows 7Refer to the PC software (ib) help guide fordetails on how to use the PC software (ib).

Reviews.Title: Nice Camera with Drawbacks!
Reviews.Author: Brian M. Edwards
Reviews.Content: This is one nice looking camera with the best quality build I think I have EVER seen in a camera, really, it screams quality at you and if you plan to use this solely for photography and NOT for video, then I give it 5 stars.The quality of the photos to my (amateur) eyes are very good even in relatively low light, the zoom is excellent (for photography) and the proprietary battery seems to last for ever. Actually, I have been using it right out of the box without ever charging and it is still going strong!The setting are easy to access, and a breeze to adjust or just leave it in I/auto as I did for great results.The BadI am quite disappointed with the video capabilities (or LACK of them!) with no optical zoom available for HD video recording unless you switch off the sound! Birthday parties and sports events will never be the same without sound and it beats me why Olympus  would come out with such a stunning camera and leave out such an important feature!I also tried shooting video in VGA mode but still no optical zoom. The camera does allow you to use the digital zoom but it turns decent quality video into a horrible blur! (I could have lived with the digital zoom for my purposes if it had worked better)Also worth a mention is the auto focus on video recording which is very slow, too slow for me.The Pro'sReally excellent quality build, this camera will last for years!!! (if you don't end up returning it)Excellent 30x optical zoom capabilityGreat looking design, compact and lightLong battery life, I still have not charge the battery yet and have taken 100 photos and 20 minutes of video.Nice LCD screenExcellent quality photos (well,to my eyes, everyone will have their own opinion)Many nice features that should satisfy most folks.2 gig built in memoryThe badNo zoom capability when recording video with soundSlow auto-focus when shooting video (too slow for me)No HDMI cable included (seems to be standard with most camera makers)The "magic" settings, are just a cheap gimmick and not worth bothering with.On the Olympus web-site, the spec's for the camera include 1080i HD video, it DOES NOT have this feature!As you can see, there are a lot of pluses with this camera and one big minus, and because I planned to use this for wildlife photography where the zoom will come in handy; as well as to record video of birthday parties and some soccer games the lack of zoom capability is hard to swallow.I was aware that the camera may have a zoom issue but the digital zoom would have been suffice it would have worked better. The auto focus on the zoom is also slow.I have also ordered the FUJI HS10 and will receive it this week. I will be doing a comparison of these two cameras and decide then which to keep!Bottom line is this is a five star camera if you plan use it for photography ONLY and a great buy for the money. However, if you also need it for video, I don't recommend it!

Reviews.Title: You Buy This For the Ultra Zoom - Great Pictures
Reviews.Author: Tom D
Reviews.Content: Some of the reviews for this camera don't make sense or are for a different model.  For example, the zoom is fully functional on my SP-800UZ in video mode.  But if you're buying this camera, you want it for the ultra-zoom, in a light, relatively compact camera that delivers sharp pictures.  There's an old expression that goes something like, "what kind of camera takes the best pictures?  The one you have with you." You may be able to get a better photo with a RAW image from a digital SLR with a $1,500 lens (or more.  This has one of the best digital zoom's I've used; most are useless.  I took photos of lighthouses over water 7 and 9 miles away and got better detail than you could see through a telescope.What's amazed me most, especially at this price point, is the sharpness of the images across the zoom range.  I'll try to post a picture of a fly and a spider on a humingbird feeder.  In the original you can see the hairs on the fly and the threadlike legs of the spider from a distance of about 15 feet.  I have another of a wild turkey at about 40 feet that shows the details of his feathers and hairy head.  People at 300' are easily recognizable.Don't expect this camera to do unreasonable things that others don't do either.  The built in flash has a limited range, maybe 10' to 12' before it starts to fall off.  On the other hand, you don't really need a flash for most indoor shots unless it's candle light.Read the manual.  Sorry, this one's only intuitive after you read the manual.  Just try to find video mode for example, without the manual...you might get there.I miss a viewfinder.  I knew this camera didn't have one and decided to live without it.  But with the ultra-zoom at full zoom, finding an airplane in a backlit sky is a hit and miss exercise; you have to back way off the zoom, find the plane, then try to zoom in while holding it on the screen.The only real complaint is that the focusing software sometimes has trouble finding what to focus on  and it takes a couple of attempts to get to the right portion of the image.  That only seems to be a problem at higher zooms.  It's especially troublesome when again you're trying to find a small plane in a large blue sky, or the flip side, a boat on a large lake while flying over.Read the instructions, practice a bit, learn the camera and unless you want to lug the big stuff, this will be your camera of choice for most occasions.

Reviews.Title: Good camera....
Reviews.Author: lordhoot "lordhoot"
Reviews.Content: Having used this camera for several days, I can basically say that this camera falls right between your basic point and shoot and ultrazoom. I will try to write this review so it won't terribly overlapped some of the other well written reviews. For those thinking this is the next step after SP590UZ, you are pretty wrong. Although zoom is extended to 30x, your camera features are more closer to your basic point and shoot camera. This is clearly indicted by the fact that Olympus did away with the electronic view finder and manual adjustment features that previous SP series had.I have read the previous reviews on video capabilities of this camera. They are mostly on the mark. I don't think Olympus cameras were any good with their videos and they are still light-years behind Canon SX20 IS and SX10 IS on that score. You don't buy this camera to take video. You buy this camera because it easier then heck to use and it got 30x optical zoom. (Of course, I would have prefer a wider angle for little less zoom.)On one super positive side, they did away with Olympus xD cards (Thank the Camera Gods!) and now you can used SD cards like any other good cameras out there. On the sadder note, they did away with the AA batteries to power this on and switch to li-on battery. Of course, li-on battery is better for video but this Olympus camera, like all others, happened to be pretty lame with their video capability so you will be shooting more photos then video. AA batteries in my book is better because you can always get your hand on more batteries. Also taking away four AA batteries made this camera too light. With no EVF and light camera, shooting at long zoom can be chore even with their well made image stabilizer system. Having wrote that, I have to say that this camera is very comfortable to hold. But like any other point and shoot that relied strictly on LCD monitor, you will suffer on very sunny days when that LCD become very hard to look through. That is why for camera of this much zoom, EVF is mandatory and this camera don't have it.The camera performed pretty well in lighted area but I regret to say that the photos comes out bit grainy and noisy as the light fades. The auto focus seem to be inconsistent in the darker places and I am not sure why. The flash works pretty well though but its hard to manage it.If you look at the back of this camera, you will realized with much horror or with some relief (depending on what you like) that there is almost no buttons back there. There is this red button for video and a button for playback mode. Rest is used for surfing the menu system. For me at least, I find it a pain to navigate through all these menus to adjust this and that as I want it. Especially when I am adjusting and adapting as I shoot. Usually most cameras of this type got EV adjustment button, self timer button, marco-micro button and all that. Not with this camera, you got to go through the menu system for just about everything. Some may like this, I did not so that is one of the reasons why I gave it only three stars.This camera is hybrid between a basic point and shoot and your latest ultrazoom. Lacking EVF and manual control features make this closer to the a basic point and shoot with a big zoom. I am not sure who wants something like this but I am sure somebody does.I hope this review complements the other reviews out there. Most are pretty good, pointing out the pros and the cons of this camera in their own colorful style.

Reviews.Title: Best Overall Value
Reviews.Author: Randolph Wein "Upto N. O'Good"
Reviews.Content: This brand new entry from Olympus still is not widely known. But along with its little brother, the SP-600UZ, it offers the most features at one of the lowest prices of any "hybrid" camera (top-end point-and-shoots that approach the quality at nowhere near the price of SLRs).Frequent promotions lower the typical shelf price of the SP-800UZ from approximately $349 to approximately $289. The 600UZ is about $100 less, but offers fewer options at reduced quality, and a zoom only half as powerful.What is to like about Olympus' new flagship? A LOT!Start with the largest lens ever on a point-and-shoot. Zoom factor always is the first feature I look for, and this is the first hybrid to reach the 30x mark. That gives MUCH flexibility for your shots, no matter the setting or subject.The second-most important feature for me is burst-shot capacity. Again Olympus shatters the standard, moving from the previous offering of one setting to five! Three are the traditional rapid-fire exposures, offering fast, faster, and fastest. At the other extreme is a setting that takes almost portrait quality shots, but with much quicker recovery time between exposures. It really is not a true burst, but a cross between burst and automatic settings.The fifth burst setting is the feature I find most useful. This sets the camera to take a quick a very short pause between each exposure to refocus and recalibrate for changes in lighting and distance. The result is much higher quality shots than with typical burst with little sacrifice of continuity.Of course all the burst settings sacrifice some of the lens excellence and flexibility offered by the special settings. However, shots still are good quality (and can be edited to become even better). And when shooting dynamic settings, such as picnics and birthday parties (but NOT fast-action sports), you are likely to get -- even if by the law of averages --  at least one good-to-excellent shot per burst.The significant negative to this otherwise wonderful camera is the ease of use. So many features are packed into the sturdy, lightweight and excellently shaped build that making them all easily accessable proved to be a challenge so far unmet.Once found, the features are excellent and give wonderful flexibility in composing and exposing your pictures.Video capability is the other most common -- but to me unfair -- criticism. The video feature is greatly improved from previous Olympus models. However, do not make the mistake of thinking this will replace or substitute for a video camera.This is a single-shot camera! It also is capable of capturing moving images and sound, but not nearly at the level of its single exposures.Overall, this model's power (size of lens, 14 mp exposures, flash flexibility, and long-lasting batteries that re-charge quickly from typical outlet converter or more slowly within the camera when connected by USB cable to a computer)and features (variety of exposure, style, and effects settings) make the SP-800UZ almost untouchable in its market niche.Factor in the regular price reductions, and to me the choice is clear. The Olympus SP-800UZ is easily the best buy in its class.

Reviews.Title: My 70th birthday gift to me; worth the 70 year wait!
Reviews.Author: Mary the Gator
Reviews.Content: This camera is an excellent choice for anyone who needs quick-grab family shots, crowded event photos, travel pictures taken from a bus window, and then miraculously, having the ability to completely capture the most exquisite architectural detail from great distance, or preserving the macro beauty of everyday items, or freezing any instant in time--enhancing, filtering, or distorting for impact.  Olympus has always provided quality cameras, I have owned/loved several, but this one is amazing for its versatility, its incredible range, its good feel in the hand, its surprisingly compact size, and its easy cperational menu. Sometimes I photograph in seconds; other times I want to tickle my left brain for hours, and this camera does it all. The Olympus SP-800UZ replaces/surpasses every camera this birthday girl has ever owned.  The 30 x optical zoom keeps me out of a lot of mischief--both aging feet can stay firmly planted on the ground! Marvelous product. Happy Birthday!

Reviews.Title: Love this camera!
Reviews.Author: D. Parker
Reviews.Content: I got my camera two days ago and I love it!  Setup was a breeze and I learned the camera after about two hours of playing with the settings.  The zoom is incredible and and super close up pictures are the best I've ever taken.  I've seen some other reviews that have been critical of the camera's few manual settings, but, seeing as how I'm an extreme amateur I like the auto settings.  Taking good pictures is more important to me than being a good photographer. I'm also not bothered by the lack of an optical eyepiece, as the LCD screen is strong and clear even in sunlight.  I was a little leary of purchasing such a new camera that had so few user reviews, but after having used it, I would make the same decision again.UPDATE:  20 months after I purchased the camera and I'm still loving it!  I've gotten some magnificent shots, ranging from a full moon with craters clearly visible to birds in my backyard feeder with the tiny seeds from the feeder showing clearly in their beaks. I've also gotten several frameworthy shots with this camera, all using the automatic settings.  This was one of the best purchases I've ever made and I would do it again in a heartbeat.

Reviews.Title: Great Little Camera; Great Value
Reviews.Author: TiRo
Reviews.Content: What I was looking for:-- More advanced than a point-and-shoot, but not as complex as a DSLR-- Well-made-- Decent, basic video capability-- Comfortable to hold and manipulate-- High level zoom-- Price: Under $300What's Great About It:-- 2MB of internal memory in addition to a card slot.  I find that saving images to internal memory is much faster than saving to a card.  Camera also has functionality for transferring photos and video from internal memory to a card inside the camera.-- Appears to be very well-made.  Although the casing is made of plastic, the camera looks and feels very solid.  My impression is that this camera will last a long time.-- Weight:  A bit heavier than a point-and-shoot, but light enough that I can easily carry it with me most places.  Because of it's size, it doesn't fit in a pocket, but it does fit in a small carry-on or large purse.-- Consistent photo quality.  I'm consistently getting excellent outdoor photos and very good indoor photos.-- The 30x optical zoom works great.  I'm getting very clear outdoor pictures at full zoom.  Indoor zoomed pictures are slightly grainy, but that's true of many cameras in this price range.-- Option of varying the resolution from 3MP to 12MP.  I rarely need 12MP, so by using a lower resolution, I get many more images before having to transfer them to a card or computer.-- Video: Exactly what I was looking for.  Great for capturing events with family and friends.  Includes decent audio that can optionally be turned off.  With audio turned off, you can zoom while filming.-- Small, light-weight Li-Ion battery.  I'm getting about 300 photos and 10-15 minutes of video per charge.  Battery recharges in about 2 hours.  I just keep two additional batteries on hand, and I'm good to go in pretty much any situation.  (I found the best prices for extra batteries here on Amazon.)-- Price:  Great value for the price.  I got it on sale at a big-box store; worth every penny.-- Very good macro and super macro.  After a bit of a learning curve, I'm now consistently getting great macro and super-macro pictures.-- Filters:  These are more fun than I expected.  I didn't think I'd use them at all, but I do.  The "coloring book" filter is great for making personalized coloring books for the children in my life.-- Includes an option to add several seconds of audio to still pictures.  Very handy for quick descriptions of pictures so you don't forget later.-- Built-in Flash:  I like the fact that it the flash never pops-up automatically.  It will fire automatically in certain modes, but if you don't want the flash at all (and I often don't), you just leave the flash closed.Could be Better, but Do-Able:-- Size:  From an ergonomic standpoint, I wish it were a little bit larger.  Initially, my hands felt cramped when using the camera, but I got used to the size after about a month.-- Menu-based controls.  In terms of both convenience and ergonomics, I strongly prefer buttons and dials.  Buttons and dials are easier for me than going through menus.  Additionally, the control (a combination button/dial) that is used to access the menu is fairly small and almost flush to the back of the camera.  I have average-size hands, and it took me awhile before I was comfortable with the menu conroller.  I imagine this would be even more challenging for someone with larger hands.I initially planned to return the camera because of the ergonomic issues.  But I only found a couple of other cameras in my price range that were more comfortable ergonomically, and both of those had too many other negatives.  I've since found a more comfortable way to hold the Olympus and am gradually getting used to the menus.  The camera does such good job in auto mode that I often just leave it there and don't bother with other options.-- No view finder:  I wish it had one, but that is becoming less of an issue the more I use the camera.-- User Guide:  Entirely digital.  If you want hardcopy, you have to print the 70+ pages yourself.  The manual is pretty good, but I'd like to see a little more detail in some areas.-- Focusing:  It took me awhile to figure out how the camera focuses.  But now that I've gotten through the learning curve, I'm consistently getting very good pictures.-- Camera cannot be used right out of the box.  It must first be initialized, a process that requires connecting the camera to a computer.  At least for me, the initialization process was not very intuitive.-- Error messages: This is probably the camera's weakest point for me.  If I'm changing settings, I sometimes get an error message saying I can't choose a particular option because it conflicts with another setting already in place, but it doesn't tell me which one.  The user guide doesn't have a chart or summary explaining this, either.  So I'm left to either trial-and-error or digging through the lengthy manual to determine which settings work with each other and which do not.Bottom Line:I wanted a camera that was between a basic point-and-shoot and a DSLR and had basic video capability.  I also had a limited budget.  This camera fits the bill.

Reviews.Title: Not the best camera in it's field. Customer support not good.
Reviews.Author: Daniel J. Burejsza
Reviews.Content: There are no manual modes for either exposure or focus. Sometimes you can trick the camera into the right exposure by selecting one of the various program options or scene modes, but there is no way to convince it to focus properly when it chooses not to. I have a bird feeder on my front porch. In low light, (like dusk), I can't get close enough to the feeder for the infrared light on the camera to help with focusing, (Birds fly away). Attempting to focus on other objects that are a similar distance away, (as the manual recommends), also does not work. In bright light it is hard to tell if the camera is in good focus because the screen is difficult to see, (there is no viewfinder to block out screen glare). The lens cap constantly falls off, exposing the lens to possible damage and there is no way to fasten on a protective uv filter.The camera comes bundled with software called "ib". This software has a bug that will not let me run it without entering an activation code. I emailed Olympus customer support several times asking for the code. They say it doesn't exist. Once they suggested that I use other software. When I suggested that I could also use another brand of camera as well, they transfered me to another department at Olympus. I have emailed them again several times and they insist that I call them by phone so that I can help resolve their problem.I am not happy with a company that wants me to spend my time repairing their mistakes.Today I would buy a camera that has a viewfinder, manual exposure, and manual focus options. Having a large zoom and a automatic camera is fine, but only if the pictures are in focus. I can use computer software to lighten or darken a picture, but there is not much you can do with a blurry picture.

Reviews.Title: Definate improvement over my previous Olympus Ultrazooms
Reviews.Author: Macuser
Reviews.Content: I have previously owned two other ultra zoom Olympus cameras (C-770UZ and SP-570UZ) and after reading some lukewarm reviews about the image quality of the SP-800UZ I was a bit hesitant to buy one, but after one day of owning it I feel pleased overall.This camera is indeed a paradox because although it apparently was intended for point and shoot novices, the image quality out of the box in iAuto mode is not that great (focus is soft and color saturation is on the flat side and there are no in camera adjustments possible to correct those deficiencies as there are on the C770UZ and SP570UZ).  However, an experienced user quickly finds out that in P (Program) mode with the ISO set at 50 and the white balance set for sunshine, the sharpness and colors in outdoor landscape shots substantially improves. Then after adding additional sharpness and color saturation to the images in a photo editing program the image quality looks stunning!  So in the end my still photos with the SP800UZ are very pleasing and satisfying.I also found the criticism about "noisy, out of focus images" in full or near full telephoto mode is unwarranted if the ISO is set at 50 and a tripod or some other support is used.  I also found the criticism about the "tiny fingernail operated control wheel" unwarranted because once you get used to it, using it becomes second nature.One criticism I would agree with is the camera occassionally has trouble focusing, but my guess is I can rectify this via more closely paying attention to where the target box is positioned.The lack of a viewfinder is a slight inconvience in some situations, but I have to admit I rarely used it on my other two Olympus ultrazooms.The 2GB of internal memory is super nice as is the cameras small size and lightweight. The new menu system is quicker and easier to use than previous Olympus systems.  Overall I can tell I am going to love this camera.

Reviews.Title: Avoid this Camera
Reviews.Author: ED Denson
Reviews.Content: I have been using Olympus SP cameras for over a decade. I started with a 2 megapixel model and each year or two bought a new one, usually to coincide with a trip I was taking abroad which I wished to document and would probably never be able to repeat. I have taken thousands and thousands of photographs with Olympus SP cameras, and have been especially impressed by and eager for extensions of the optical zooms as I am often at some distance from the subject of my photos (eagles nesting in Alaska, Penguins ashore in Antarctica, statues at the top of some very tall column in Barcelona, a painting high on a wall in Eureka, my dog frisking in the field at home). You can imagine then how I looked forward to getting the SP-800UZ with both an increase in zoom (from 26-30) and megapixels. I expected to be able to get better photos of the same type of subjects as I had been shooting, and with the 15% increase in zoom, some new subjects which had been previously out of my reach. I got the SP-800UZ for a cruise trip from London across the North Atlantic to Nova Scotia and then Florida.  We had two stops in Iceland and I was determined to see the great waterfalls, get some shots of the scenery sailing into and out of the ports,  and take in the London scenes.I was disappointed in this camera almost from the outset. I had to give up and stop using it a few days into the cruise and substitute my older SP which I had brought along as a backup in case something happened to the SP 800UZ. Here are the problems: the new camera has been redesigned. It is smaller, and lighter, than its predecessors. Being also rated at higher megapixels and optical zoom this sounds like a win-win-win-win. But the redesign has made the handle - that protrusion at the front right of the camera- smaller. When you grip the camera your palm tends to rest on the control panel of the device, which is at the right rear. Your palm resets the controls, sometimes while you are shooting. I am not a power user. I want automatic focus and stability controls on and I'm happy.  I have had to stop and manually adjust the settings back to those settings virtually every shot I have taken. This means no more fast shots - no more seeing something interesting and whipping the camera round to get it. Or rather it means more blurry shots of something which might have been a good photo (see focus below, too). These "bus window" shots are vital to those of us who can travel, but can't hire a private vehicle in each port.Moreover the auto-focus is at the same time poor, and slow. You have to wait much longer than with the prior cameras in this line before the camera is satisfied that it has a focus. And even then it is usually wrong. You won't notice this until you load the photos onto your computer and see them at screen size. They may look ok in the display on the camera back but they won't on the computer, especially if you crop or enlarge them (the point of having 14 megapixels).  if you want to be sure of your shot as you take it, shoot, then set the camera to display so you can see the shots you have taken. Pick one, then zoom in on the photo. It will likely tend to blur out quick early in the zoom. If you have a stationary target and all the time in the world you can delete the poorly focused shots and repeat them until you get something better. I usually have a target which is moving relative to me, and no time to get more than that 1st shot. That first shot which has been so satisfactory to me on my earlier Olympus cameras, and so disappointingly elusive with this one.Shots at the full zoom are the worst, focus-wise. I did not find that the extra 15% of zoom got me any improvement in photo quality at all. All you get, in effect, is an extra extension of zoom which is entirely lost in the blur of going beyond the capacity of the camera to focus.And then there is the battery situation. The earlier cameras took 4xAA batteries. The new one takes one of those light, slim, lithium batteries which are expensive, difficult to find while traveling, require a special charger, are incompatible from one brand of camera to another, and, just for the kicker, don't last long in this camera. I found that if I were going on an all-day trip - and an-all day trip on a cruise is about 6 hours- I should take at least two extra batteries with me. Batteries which I had to buy before the trip and spend some time charging on the ship the evening prior to the trip.Another way the camera was made smaller, and lighter, was by eliminating the viewfinder. The theory is that the display is now so improved that the sun will not wash it out when you are shooting outdoors, so you don't need the viewfinder. This theory is mistaken.Ok, lets sum up: The placement of the controls and the grip on the camera case create a design disaster making it very difficult to rely on the settings when you shoot. The auto-focus is very slow and not very good, making quick photos almost impossible to successfully shoot. The display will wash out in strong light so you'll have to take some shots without being able to frame the picture you are taking -which means some people will lose their heads or feet. The battery is expensive, doesn't last long when you are using the camera, and often incompatible with similar batteries in other cameras (and their chargers) so don't count on being able to borrow from your shipmate, or to help them out.If all you want to do is take routine snapshots of things that are relatively close to you and don't move, which you can redo if you are not pleased with the first try, and if you're ok with pictures that are more or less in focus, this camera will probably work for you. So will many much simpler, cheaper cameras. No matter what your goal this is not the camera to buy if you have any alternatives at all. I'm going to sell mine, cheap. My advice is: don't buy it.

Reviews.Title: I have used many cameras in past 50 years but..
Reviews.Author: Peakperformance Ken
Reviews.Content: I have used many cameras in 50+ years and am relatively computer knowledgable but this camera is the most COUNTER intuitive piece of equipment that I have ever had the displeasure to use. If you try to change certain settings it gives you a conflict warning WITHOUT telling you what the conflict is so you waste great amounts of time trying to make the change you want without a settings conflict !! (I have been unsuccessful thus far) Even something as simple as erasing images has been made more difficult than it needs to be.Previously I had used the older OM4 cameras which were cutting edge as well as the research quality microscopes/optics so it is not as I am unfamilar with optics but the menu system on this camera is ridiculous and because of that it is simply too frustrating to use. The automatic focus does not always work and at those times I would like to focus manually but that is not possible with this camera. There is NO manual shipped with the camera but rather some weak orientation to the basic functions. One a positive note the LCD screen is very bright and makes viewing it outdoors far easier than I have seen with many other digital cameras/camcorders.Years ago if this was available I would have recommended it only to my enemies but I cannot be that way now so I simply do not recommend it as there are other choices today that are far better and much less frustrating.

Reviews.Title: Not A Point And Shoot
Reviews.Author: Jodee "http://www.jodeesweb.com"
Reviews.Content: I have been an Olympus owner for many years, that is what lead me to upgrade my old Olympus with the Olympus SP-800UZ. When I took it out of the box, I was amazed at how professional the camera looks. I am not a professional, and should have learned more about the camera before I took pictures of my little girls three year birthday. Looking at the pictures on the LCD screen, I thought I was taking amazing photos. But a couple of days later, when I uploaded them to my computer, I was horrible disappointed. The pictures looked grainy and down right horrible. I started reading the instructions, and playing around with the camera. After an hour or so, I started taking some pretty good pictures. I found some really amazing settings to make a few professional looking photographs. I need to practice some more, but I believe in the end, this will be a very good camera for me.So all in all, if you want a point and shoot camera, this is not going to be for you. But if you want to take the time to learn the proper way to use the camera, and don't mind changing settings, in time, you will be making some really beautiful photographs.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera for sports!
Reviews.Author: kcarter71
Reviews.Content: I will not go into a lot of detail about the features because other people already have. I also can not rate this cameras video because I have a great video camera and have not tried to use this camera for video. I bought this camera specifically for taking pictures of my daughters playing sports. I have to say it is awesome when I first got the camera it took me a couple of volleyball matches before I figured out how to set up the camera to take the best action shots. But now I am taking pictures of track meets and it is better than I thought it was going to be. I can sit at the top of the stands and take pictures of my daughter on the other side of the track running and they come out like I was right next to her taking the picture and there is no blurry pictures.I also took pictures of the high jump, long jump and hurdles and they were awesome I can not say enough good things about this camera for action shots. Better than I expected at a better price!

Reviews.Title: I really wanted to like this camera....
Reviews.Author: SueChem
Reviews.Content: Let me start this review by saying I REALLY wanted to love this camera.  I haven't bought myself a new camera in years, and I have an old Olympus C740UZ that I just love (it has taken a beating and still takes awesome pictures).  In December 2006 I had bought a new Olympus SP-510 and returned it, but I read some good reviews on the SP800-UZ so I figured I'd give Olympus another chance.I am definitely not a professional photographer, but I am certainly an above average amateur.  I have gigs of pictures and everyone is always complementing me on my shots.I will say that yes, you can take amazing pictures with this camera...IF you have everything set exactly right and the time to fiddle with it between shots.  Not practical if you are shooting your kid or pet doing something cute right now!  As far as snap and shoot forget it.Pros:-Very nice design, fits well in my hand and controls were easy to use and accessible.-Beautiful large display screen.-Amazing zoom (see also cons).Cons:-Focuses slowly and often not on the desired target.-Pictures were often over/underexposed and colors tended to be off.-You DEFINITELY need a tripod if you go over about 15x optical zoom.I took almost 500 pictures with this camera over the period of about two weeks under many different light conditions.  On the iAuto mode (their snap and shoot setting) even on a bright sunny day, many of the pictures of my daughter playing in the pool were blurry.  I couldn't believe it! Pictures of her playing at a playground at dusk were underexposed on almost every scene setting, and the pink of her skirt was not right in any of the shots.Menu choices are often odd too.  For example, on the iAuto mode, you cannot set the rapid shutter settings.  Attempting to allow digital zoom for shooting video always gave me an error message that I had incompatible settings.Reflections (especially bright sun on yellow) completely wash out to white.  I tried changing the shadow setting, the white balance and just about every mode, but couldn't get the shots of black-eyed Susan's not to have white spots on them.  My old Olympus and my daughter's little Kodak did not have this issue, they correctly captured the light yellow my eye saw.If you max the optical zoom, even if you stabilize the camera, clicking the shutter is often enough to blur the shot.  I did get one good shot of a bluebird fairly far away, but I reviewed the shot, went to take another and the camera was locked up!  By the time I remedied the situation, he was gone.  This is ultimately why I returned the camera (like I said I REALLY wanted to like it).  I returned the camera because about 50% of the time when I went from reviewing a shot to try to take another picture it would lock up.  It locked so badly that it would only reset by popping out the battery!Needless to say, I was extremely disappointed in this camera, and am definitely NOT buying another Olympus!

Reviews.Title: Do Not Recommend
Reviews.Author: Katherine Gonzalez
Reviews.Content: I have purchased several cameras over the past year, and this is by far the worse camera I have ever bought. It may have 30x Wide Optical Zoom, but what good is that when it takes so long for it to focus and the pic caputred (after it take so long to focus) comes out blurry. I would not recommend this product to anyone. I have a 3 year old son and one on the way and need a camera that will get good shots on moment notice, not miss a great shot because the camera is trying to focus.

Reviews.Title: Olympus SP 800 UZ review
Reviews.Author: G. Alldredge
Reviews.Content: I'm an Olympus fan with an E-620 as my top DSLR.  I really liked the SP 550 UZ when it was fairly new.  I then bought an SP 565 UZ and then an SP 590 UZ.  The Olympus SP 800 UZ is one of those new 'mirror-less' point-and-shoots that tries to make up for no viewfinder by having a bright, well designed screen.  I found the 800 UZ very difficult to see in bright sunlight.  I longed for my 590 UZ with a view finder.  Indoors, the 800 UZ is a dream as to scene/shot preview.  Other than the outdoors focus problem, I really like the 800 UZ.  The quality of image output was above par for this price range camera.

Reviews.Title: Needs Viewfinder
Reviews.Author: Martin B. Smith "Chief Exec"
Reviews.Content: This is a great camera with one huge exception. You have to hold it away from you to take a picture as there is no viewfinder to use. This is a huge mistake as because of the extreme magnification it is virtually impossible to hold the camera so that it is steady enough to take a picture. Fantastic camera with a major, major flaw. Maybe Olympus with figure this out for the next version as the camera is close to useless as it is unless you go to the trouble of setting up and using a tripod. The major benefit of the extreme zoom is therefor negated.

Reviews.Title: What a GREAT CAMERA !! Totally exceeded my expectations!
Reviews.Author: Helen S.
Reviews.Content: I had been wanting a new camera for awhile. I love taking nature pic's, along with candid family pic's , but nature is my favorite. With all the settings on the camera there is no way you can miss your shot ! The pic's are so crisp and clear, even if zoomed to maximum . The auto stabilization is outta this world !! Literally !! The first night I had it , we had a full moon. Every one was posting pic's on FB, and they were a white circle... so I took my camera out and took a few shots, I was amazed !! My husband joked that he could see the flag the astronauts left. All the craters,etc.... where CRISP and CLEAR !!! I posted it on FB and it looked amazing !!On long distance shots like that, you do have to have something to prop against, because the stabilization won't work if ur hands are shaking...LOL.A few nights later the moon was bright orange when it came up... and I also got the same results on it.... absolutely wonderful pic's !!I have taken pic's of alligators, fish jumping out of water, birds in flight, and on and on...I have not used the video yet.This camera is very easy to figure out. Having a blast with it !!The only problem I have found with this camera is that if the sun is in front of you, even with flash the pic's are somewhat dark.Will return with comment whenever I use the video part. But As for the Camera and the Pic's it takes.... GREAT CAMERA !! ESPECIALLY for the price !!The only actual complaint I have is that it did not list that it came with USB cable, so I ordered one... But it was not expensive and now I have 2.Overall.... LOVE my camera !!!

Reviews.Title: Does it all
Reviews.Author: CnC
Reviews.Content: Camera has a great feel.  Great screen even in direct sun.  Zoom is amazing.  Very versatile.  Outstanding picture quality.

Reviews.Title: Slow, poor low light performance
Reviews.Author: Sergey Kiselev "skiselev"
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera at Costco as an upgrade for my point and shoot camera (Fujifilm F72Exr), with main goal to take pictures of my kids, and do some nature photography. I tried it many times in different conditions, and was not satisfied by its performance. I returned it after two weeks or so.Cons:- Poor low light performance (by low light here I mean indoor photography with normal room lighting, without using flash). Very noisy at high ISO (800 and more)- Slow to focus and has a significant shutter lag. My kids run/turn away before it takes a picture.- Image stabilization is ineffective with a long zoom (I guess more than x10).- No viewfinder one might expect on wanna-be-SLR camera.Pros:- Beautiful colors (providing that there is enough lighting)- Battery life is OK (enough for a day of shooting)- Easy to use, controls are located convenientlyConclusion: Get an SLR for taking pictures of kids in a low light :-)  Or no more than x12 zoom camera for trips (a compact zoom, like Panasonic ZS-series or Fujifilm F-series). x30 zoom is useless without a tripod.

Reviews.Title: Olympus SP800UZ
Reviews.Author: Paul W. Schoen "trainmaster"
Reviews.Content: This is my 3rd Olympus camera and this is undeniably the best one yet. The Olympus SP800UZ is a great compact camera.  It may not be as light-sensitive as the SLRs but it takes great pictures with fantastic zoom capability.  Have only taken approximately 250 pictures and have only found fault with a handful, and these I attribute to my during the learning phase of camera usage. Overall I feel this was a good solid investment in my photography journey.

Reviews.Title: Love this Camera
Reviews.Author: lsutigr
Reviews.Content: I love this camera. The picture quality is amazing and you can't beat the 30x zoom! My only complaint is the battery life. It's not that long, but I'm going to order a back up battery so I'll always have one charged. Other than that, I am very pleased with my purchase and would recommend this camera to anyone.

Reviews.Title: Disappointed :(
Reviews.Author: Roseanne G.
Reviews.Content: I tried so hard to like this camera. Took many pictures and used most of the settings(yes, I did read the manual.) But I have to say, only had about two or three "clear" shots out of the bunch. I took a picture and took the same picture with my Kodak 14mp. My Kodak was far more sharper than this camera.  I loved the fact of the 30x zoom (my Kodak only has 5x) but what good is it if I can't get the crisp pictures I want. Sent back today...

Reviews.Title: Amazing Camera
Reviews.Author: Henry Wolford
Reviews.Content: Simply an amazing camera.  There really is not a need to have a video camera and a still camera any more.  This camera will do both.  Internal memory stores more than 30 minutes of HD video or 400+ photos. Add up to a 8GB and get four times the storage more.  The telephoto is HUGE.  Stock, out of the box, I put the camera on a tripod and took a photo of the full moon with the quality of a telescope.  Even without the macro or super-macro turned on, I can focus blades of grass at less than an inch.  Telephoto is roughly 28mm to 480mm.  On screen menu of features means you can shift settings on the fly without leaving your subject.  SLR body type performance in a compact size.  Awesome!

Reviews.Title: olympus camera
Reviews.Author: P. beaver "dog lover"
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera for the 30x optical zoom.  I like everything about it except the lens cap.  It is  not attached and pops off if you forget to take it off before you turn it on.  I t takes great pictures and has lots of options to give you great photos. The other negative is no guide book except on line which means if you want to carry it with you - you have to download and print the manual- not user friendly.

Reviews.Title: Not user-friendly
Reviews.Author: Ron Supp "dont have a cow man"
Reviews.Content: Received this camera as a gift and have had trouble with it from day one. It has a lot of nifty settings, but if you just want a simple point and shoot camera and don't want the hassle of figuring out how to operate it, pass on the Olympus SP 800uz. There is no guarantee the picture taken will look even remotely like what is photographed. Not that it isn't slightly different, it is radically different - with a yellow cast to it. Not the best camera for indoor shooting, but does well if outside. Camera will not work if not kept routinely updated, but will not alert the owner to necessary updates. If not updated, forget about uploading any pictures from the camera to a computer. It will simply say "There is no new media to import". It's completely frustrating, unreliable, complicated, and not worth the high price tag.

Reviews.Title: OLympus fixed lens zoom point and shoot
Reviews.Author: Charles W. Riendeau "Deaubooks"
Reviews.Content: This Olympus point and shoot looks good and handles well.  It has a multitude of options with which I am still becoming familiar.The picture quality in comparison with a Lumix is superior with roughly the same pixels.  The exposure system of the Olympus definitely outdid the Lumix when challenged with a bright light source in the form of the setting sun with clouds.  Normally, direct sun causes a large flaring image with many digital cameras.  The exposure system in the Olympus compensated for this and allowed a more crips circular image of the sun to appear. With ambient light it is very difficult to get a blurr free picture unless you use flash.  This may be solveable if the ISO is changed to a faster speed.  It has a manual max of 3200.  No experiments with that as yet.Downsides so far are:  At maximum 30x zoom, it is nearly impossible to handhold a shot and get a sharp image.  So, put it on a tripod or monopod when using the extreme magnification.

Reviews.Title: great camera for the price
Reviews.Author: photofreak
Reviews.Content: for an automatic camera it can do some amazing things.. the zoom is outstanding,little tricky at first with the total zoom to focus but in no time you will get it...would recommend to any who want anadvanced camera but do not want to set all kind of things...only drawback is there is no hard copy manuel as it is loaded on camera wich does come in handy at time but it would be nice to be able to study a book while not using the camera....you can buy one on website for $10 or download and print it, whitch is what i did.

Reviews.Title: Don't like it, waste of money.
Reviews.Author: Booklover Karen "KarenCC"
Reviews.Content: I read the many reviews here on Amazon, and having found a great price, I bought one.  Wish I had saved my money.  Yes, it does have a long range zoom, but for me, the camera is hard to hold and shakes.  My 12 year old had a little better luck with the zoom, but admitted she was tired of getting too many bad shots.  I have owned a Panasonic/Lumix for years and love it! I have had alot of compliments on the quality of my photos, I do not see the quality with the Olympus.  I have owned the camera for 7 months, took it on a whale watch and some once in a life time trips to get long range photos. Like I said, hard to hold.  Blurry photos even without the long zoom.  Quality of photos terrible. Even using the different settings does not make a better photo.  I now leave it home in the box and don't bother with it.  Very unhappy with my purchase.  One year later update:  still unhappy.  Going to France and leaving the camera home.  I dropped my other camera in a parking lot but it still works even though screen cracked.  I will be taking that camera with me. Very disappointed with my purchase, hope I can unload it somewhere.

Reviews.Title: Olympus SP-800UZ  Great Camera!
Reviews.Author: M. Zamora
Reviews.Content: Purchased this camera after having bought, and subsequently returned, a Nikon that we were not pleased with.  We'd previously had an Olympus that was accidently dropped. It was several years old and would have been prohibitively expensive to repair.  We are so pleased with this Olympus SP-800UZ camera.  We are in a business that requires very detailed close-ups of antique coins, stamps, political buttons etc. and the 30x zoom is just the ticket!  Also, I've used many different photographic software programs over the years and the Olympus Master software is the most intuitive and user-friendly I've ever found.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera!
Reviews.Author: Dpnna K. Matoes
Reviews.Content: I love all the features this camera has to offer.  I've done photography professionally, and the picture quality is superb.  I totally recommend it.  Enjoy all the possibilities!

Reviews.Title: Pure Olympus Camera Fun
Reviews.Author: Diarmuid P. Harrington "Local Artist"
Reviews.Content: This is a fun Camera to use. I don't have all the bells and whistles down yet,but I have taken Head Shots and some very nice vistas with this Olympus. As usual the Japanese Quality is there. It is easy to charge the battery. It can also take Viedo. You will need a tripod to take photographs using the zoom. It is worthwhile to buy the camera cas.This camera can make you into a real Pro in a very short time.Sincerely,  Diarmuid Harrington

Reviews.Title: MACINTOSH USERS CAN GET A MANUAL!
Reviews.Author: Silly Willey "Lee"
Reviews.Content: I was so disappointed that there was not a written manual with the camera. I could not download the manual from my camera as I have a Mac computer and the System Requirements state in very small letters on the phamphlet; Windows XP (SP2 or later) or Windows Vista and Windows 7. I thought, oh no. This wasn't stated in any of the descriptions I read about this camera. And many of you may have Macs. I also read a lot of negative reviews that it was aggravating to have to go iINTO the camera to look up what you want to know on a certain procedure with out a manuel to look in right in front of you.Well, I hope that I have come to your rescue with both these issues. All you need to do is type in Olympus SP-800UZ/manual on your computers search and you will be able to print out a detailed manuel. Just look for the sight that says" manuel" on the page that comes up first. Have plenty of paper and black ink ready as this manuel is very large, but explains every use of this camera without having to go into your camera. The pictures are very detailed and easy to follow. It is approx. 80 pages deep (printed on one side).  One part of the manuel (the back part of the manual) is the same thing as the pamphlet that came with the camera, which didn't tell you a whole lot, but the instructions itself is great! I now am very pleased with this camera and for what it costs, it does a great job and really is easy to use. Happy photography with your Olympus SP-800UZ

Reviews.Title: best camera I've owned!
Reviews.Author: Rachel Young "rlflyer226"
Reviews.Content: This camera takes amazingly clear pictures! Esspecially outside. The HD video is spectacular, however, you do need the proper video card setup on your computer to view them once you upload and save them. I have been an amature photographer for the past 7 years and upgraded from an 8MP Digital SLR to this camera. And I have to say, it's the best choice I could have made. I love Olympus. Their cameras are built to last. I was looking at Nikon first but this camera was half the price for all the same features. It is compact enough for vacations or everyday use. The only downside I have is that the battery doesn't last as long as I expected so I recommend buying a second battery. Otherwise this little thing is ready to go when you are. It is an all around great camera and it will be years before I need to upgrade again!

Reviews.Title: Great pictures from trip to South Africa
Reviews.Author: Lucia R
Reviews.Content: While trying to find if an underwater housing is available for this camera, I ran across quite a few negative reviews on other sites.I gotta say though - I'm surprised by all the negative comments.  We bought the camera (including 2 GB card and case) at Costco a couple of days before a trip to South Africa.  Well, I was thrilled with the results and I've gotten lots of compliments on some of our pictures - were able to get amazingly clear close-ups of animals.  At that point we had not even completely figured out all the options but pictures still turned out great.  Others on our trip had larger more expensive camera and were impressed with our results.Some comments on things mentioned by others...1 camera size - I love the fact that it's small and don't know understand some saying it should be bigger/heavier.2 menu based controls - doesn't bother me at all.3 multiple shot options - these are very handy and very clear - took shots of car driving by just to see how it worked - very impressed with the clarity - good to use with moving animals.4 video - a bit disappointed that you can't use zoom while recording - didn't know until now that if you turn off sound you can zoom - I zoomed first then used video which was ok but not great - no complaints about video quality.5 lack of viewfinder - I was worried about this but now I don't even miss it.If anyone wants to view some of the photos from trip to South Africa, here's a link.  Not all of these are great - like I said earlier, we were still learning how to use the camera.[...]

Reviews.Title: Excellent Camera - Great for Travel
Reviews.Author: Ronald J. Stocum "world traveler"
Reviews.Content: Olympus SP-800UZ 14MP Digital Camera with 30x Wide Angle Dual Image Stabilized Zoom and 3.0 inch LCD -This camera iseverything the "true photographer" says it is. With the image stabilizer I find that even at 30x I can get great pictures without a tripod. I was able to get a great pix of the moon with all its valleys- I had to adjust the exposure rate to +2.0 and at 30x was able to get a great shot-hand held. I also found the laser beam with the flash eliminated hot spots that usually come with this typical point and shoot camera. The zoom range is excellent and when shooting motion using the optical setting you can shoot the full range of the zoom. You will not get sound on the optical setting. You have to use the digital setting for this and not have the zoom. The special effect features are fun and the panorama feature is excellent. I have used many cameras since 1969 and this camera is the best I have owned so far for the money. I have seen many travelers buy cameras with optional lens and they look professional but by the time they decide which lens to use and get everything setup they have lost the shot. This camera will allow you to get the shot quickly since you have the zoom capability in one lens. Another feature is that you have to manually engage the flash so you will not be taking flash pictures accidentally where you are not allowed to use the flash. Great Purchase.

Reviews.Title: best super zoom for price
Reviews.Author: Shinigami "Shinigami"
Reviews.Content: For $250 (July 4th sale), I was finally convinced to buy it. I am planning to use it for vacation in Hawaii.  My prime purpose for getting this camera is the super zoom. Its cheaper compared to other super zoom cameras because they took off a lot of extras which I rarely or don't use such as: -view finder-horse shoe-manual (you can download this)-software (you can download this as needed)-video quality is minimal(this is not designed for this, get a video camera if you love taking videos.Don't buy it if you need those items listed.

Reviews.Title: Terrific Camera!
Reviews.Author: R. Colley "~~RC~~"
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera in April and am very pleased. Picture quality and zoom are excellent. The software that came with it is a little clunky and I'll be looking for something different. I am very pleased with this purchase.

Reviews.Title: hunting for software
Reviews.Author: P. Allen
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera and it seems great except there is no software with it for downloading the pictures from the camera and I haven't found anything yet searching the web so until I can save the pictures I already took I won't get much use out of the camera.  I was informed there is a manual available for the camera that can be downloaded from the manufacturers website but I haven't found that yet either.  A hard copy manual should be included along with some software.  I was hoping, since I got the better model in this line, that I wouldn't have to buy a picture card for a while since the internal memory is more than adequate for my general purposes.If anyone knows of a download site for the software for this puppy, I'd love to know.  If I don't find one soon I may have to return the camera.

Reviews.Title: Stunning abilities
Reviews.Author: K. Monahan "freewheeler"
Reviews.Content: I got this camera because I needed a long zoom, mostly for bird photos.  It's only my second digital cam, after my Nikon Coolpix S640.  It's nice that it can shoot videos, but I'm partial to stills.  The shots I've gotten so far with the SP800-UZ have mostly been spectacular!  I mean professional quality!  The resolution is excellent, and it has two ways of magnifying the optical zoom: fine zoom, and digital zoom.  It can shoot a leaf from twenty feet away and make it look like a macro shot.  Speaking of macro, it can focus to within 1cm of the subject in Super Macro mode!  It's not great in low light, but a long zoom and low light ability are usually mutually exclusive.  It has a power-saver mode which I use most of the time, which greatly extends battery life.  It has lots of modes which let you express yourself, my favorite being Magic Drawing mode, which takes photos which look like pencil sketches.  It takes panoramic shots and stitches them together in-camera (my Nikon requires uploading to a computer) The Olympus photo-handling system seems to be better than that of Nikon.  It's feather-light for a camera with such a long zoom (less than a pound).  It does seem to have a long shutter delay, and the off-center tripod mount makes it off-balance on a small tripod.  Overall, it's a stunner!

Reviews.Title: Pleased with my 5th digital camera
Reviews.Author: W. Parker
Reviews.Content: I started digital photography in 2005 with an Olympus C765-uz, 4 mp with which I got some of the best shots I've ever taken, especially with the super macro.  Despite later adding two Canon dslr's and a Panasomic Lumix, I was still looking for a higher megapixel version of the 765 and have found it in the 800uz.  Things I like about the 800 uz are its size and feel, its comparatively quick shutter response, the ease of menu usage, much higher mp's, and its flexibility from quality super macro to 30x zoom all in one camera.  Compared to the older Olympus and the Panasomic, visibility with the view screen is much better in bright light which makes up somewhat for the lack of a viewfinder.  Things I don't like are having to recharge batteries in the camera (no external battery charger provided), and the shorter battery life compared to any of the above-mentioned cameras, at least for my first usage.  Fortunately, the one I got came with 3 batteries.  Great camera for the price.Following up after about 6 months of usage, I have additional comments.  The camera continues to be excellent for scenes, panoramas, and reasonable zooms with good light, especially of things like butterflies and dragonflies.  Photo quality, of birds for example, at the highest zoom is usually fair to poor.  I've found a dilemma in usage in that you have to re-set almost everything every time the camera is turned off, but if you leave it on in anticipation of subjects, then the battery goes rather quickly.  I have found myself going back to the smaller Panasonic and larger Canon more often in recent months, although I would still favor this camera for its diversity when I'm on longer hikes and not wanting to weigh myself down with a dslr and its lenses.

Reviews.Title: Room for Improvement
Reviews.Author: MLB
Reviews.Content: I've been using high zoom digital cameras for several years and take all sorts of pictures.  I like the ease of a high zoom point and shoot with some manual control.  I decided to try the new Olympus because of 30x zoom capabilities and other features.  The creative art filter to make a picture look like a drawing is pretty neat and has proven to be useful.The SP800uz doesn't seem to have the same vibrant color and clarity that my previous digital offered.  The auto focus is inconsistent.  Sometimes it takes multiple refocus attempts and/or multiple shots to get a clear picture.  This is very frustrating when a great shot is lost due to the camera's inability to focus (even with the auto focus assist light).  The camera needs the stability of a tripod even when it's not at full zoom, despite the fact that it's supposed to have dual image stabilization.I've also noticed that the white balance is off.  Sometimes the colors are right on and other times (same setting and lighting) they come out with a yellowish tint.The 800uz boasts of a 3" LCD viewing screen.  This is deceptive as it only uses about 2" of the screen for typical picture display with a black border on each side.  I contacted Olympus regarding this, after several days they replied only to inform me that this is normal and the only way you get use of the full 3" screen would be to change the quality setting to 16:9 mode or while shooting video.  Overall, I cannot give this purchase a rating higher than okay/average, due to the inconsistent performance and average battery life.  At this point, there's not much support on the Olympus website either.

Reviews.Title: Picture Quality is not good
Reviews.Author: Rafael
Reviews.Content: I was happy to see a camera with 30x zoom, but I could not accept the image quality.Amazon was very generous with their return policy, and I'm now a very happy owner of a Canon EOS 60D.I suggest you to compare camera sample images at [...] before choosing a camera.

Reviews.Title: using the long zoom effectively
Reviews.Author: Yuen Chung Kwong
Reviews.Content: since the main attraction of this camera is the long zoom, your happiness with it much depends on your experience taking telephotosas there is no viewfinder, you have to hold it in front of your face looking at the screen, and of course you will find the telephoto image unstable with hand movement; the solution I found was to fix a short handle to the camera: I used a unextended monopod, but any handle up to 2 feet would doholding the end of the stick in the left hand and the camera with the right, the image is much more steady; provided the object is well illuminated and the camera sets a short exposure time, the picture would be fairly decentI find the colours of SP800 not as good as those of SP550, but better than PM1; generally, Olympus colours are not as good as those of Nikon; the user interface of sp800 also makes it a bit hard to use, but since its price is now $200+, it definitely provides good value

Reviews.Title: Awesome Camera
Reviews.Author: Nicole Kendall "Nicole"
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera from another retailer, but thought that writing the review would help others on here.I have had this camera for about a year and love it. I love the various shooting features like pet mode, beach/snow, etc. I love using the 30x wide optical zoom because it gets so much more of the scene that your trying to get. Pictures come out crisp looking for being 14 megapixels.

Reviews.Title: Great camera.
Reviews.Author: John Nickias Jr.
Reviews.Content: I've had this camera while.  I've played with the panoramic feature which is cool and works ever so neat.  I mainly use it for point and shoot pics, which this camera is overkill for, but it takes those so great.

Reviews.Title: Olympus SP-800UZ 14 MP 30X
Reviews.Author: Lance J Bullion
Reviews.Content: This camera is a different bird , it has limited aperture and sutter settings but the ones that come Auto do the job I think . I just got it but I put through alot of test , It's a qaulity product and some settings get me the very truest color reproduction that I've ever seem .  This camera is for a patient person , and good for people who like point and shoot cameras,set on Auto it gives some good pics , other settings limit or hender the zoom but the incadesent light setting is amazing , the auto zoom works really well indoors .I haven't got a chance to take it outdoors so this review is only half complete.  I shoot the moon alot and have not given it this test yet, one does have to have a steady hand for this bird but well worth the money I paid ,$100 used and it looks and seems brand new.I'm stoked to have this in my little collection.

Reviews.Title: Still a decent camera if you know its limitations
Reviews.Author: mmsumulong "mmsumulong"
Reviews.Content: There are a lot of negative things being said about this camera. But after almost two years and having a DSLR, I still get to use this camera and take great pictures. No it's not fast, it does not have great ISO capabilities but the zoom features are still worth it. Imagine a 300-800mm Sigma lens can cost around $6,500 to $8,000 and this cost a fraction of that. For the amateur that I am and you know its limitations and capabilities, this camera still serves its purpose. I must admit though it's not the best, but at times it can replace and even do things my DSLR can't.

Reviews.Title: NICE CAMERA - WITH SOME "IF ONLYS"
Reviews.Author: Jeanie from Dallas
Reviews.Content: I kid you not when I say I had six $300 - $400 cameras in a 2 week period, and sent them all back except this one!!  I've had several brands, several zoom-capabilities, several different kinds of features, etc.What I was specifically looking for was a camera that could: 1) Zoom quite a ways and still get crisp clear shots; 2) a camera that would take clear photos in dim lighting, turning out a clear clean shot even without a flash, and 3) a camera that can take photos in a dimly lit place and NOT have those pictures look pink or red. It's a bulky camera, so you can't stick it in your pocket.  I would recommend this camera as a stepping stone for learning from.  Technology is constantly moving forward.I had a newer version of this camera for 6 months, took it on 2 vacations, and most of the photos turned out blurry and pink, no matter what I did. I tried every setting, every feature, and could not resolve the problems. The newer verion had more bells and whistles (24x optical zoom, 1080 video, and much more) but for some reason, it isn't half the camera this one is.  I sent it back.I stand amazed at how CLEAR and perfect the photos are with this SP-800UZ camera, even when fully zoomed.  I agree with some of the reviews I've read, but you have to realize a few things about cameras: none of them deliver it all; they all fall short in one way or another; you have to know exactly what features you really need from a camera, then get the camera that meets those needs.  It's just that simple. (Unless you're a professional photographer and can afford a camera that costs you thousands of dollars).I had to download the manual from the Internet.  It's right there, and you can also print it off.  Read the manual.  This camera is worth the trouble.  I plan to squeeze out every bit of capability and technology I can.Thank you.

Reviews.Title: Very pleased
Reviews.Author: Alejo Guevara Jr.
Reviews.Content: I'm very pleased with the picture quality, and the high def video.  I do have trouble steadying the camera for the videos, but I'm trying to work on improving that.  Of course, the tighter you zoom in, the more "jittery" the video gets.  It's a matter of trying to steady the camera.  I love the high def pictures, and the 30X zoom is absolutely amazing!  I can buy tickets to a concert, be sitting a ways back, and STILL get some very nice pictures!  I love it!!!

Reviews.Title: Not terrible, but could be good
Reviews.Author: Cosmo
Reviews.Content: So I got this camera just a few months ago and quite honestly I'm torn.  The camera has plenty of good qualities and just as many bad qualities.The Pros:*Exceptional zoom (30x optical is unheard of on a camera like this)*Great picture quality at 14 mega pixels*HD video always looks great*Fairly compact.  Just a little too big to fit in one's pockets, but not bulky at all.*Nice big screen makes life way easier when you can see the picture you just took.The Cons:*Battery life is horrid.  Mine usually lasts just a few hours on a full charge.  I blame the big screen and the camera having to work to adjust the giant lens.  Even when avoiding adjusting the zoom, don't expect much from one battery.  Always carry at least one spare if you are going to be out for a whole day.*Auto focus can be very slow at times.  This is especially frustrating when you are trying to get a pic of moving wildlife or something like that.  Also the camera seems to over or under focus more than any other camera I have used.*The menu is a bit confusing at first.  It's even more frustrating when you want to change a setting but the camera won't let you and only says "Conflicting Settings" but doesn't want to tell you what you need to change to have unconflicting settings.*The special settings such as the "auto panorama" and, my personal favorite, "tracking focus," though great when they work, usually don't work.  The auto panorama stitches together a series of pics to make one big picture, only problem is the camera doesn't always take the picture in the right place so by no fault of your own the pics frequently don't line up correctly.  And the auto tracking function rarely tracks the right thing you select, and when it actually does track the right thing it usually doesn't focus on it correctly.And I'm not judging this whole model of camera on this, but just months after I got it the flash broke.  Just one more thing about this camera that leaves me un-impressed.  Did I just get a faulty unit, or are they all cheapo?Personally, I would not recommended it to anyone who wants to do anything more than a point and click camera can offer.  Basically, that's all this camera is is a larger version of this:  Olympus FE370 8MP Digital Camera with 5x Optical Dual Image Stabilized Zoom (Silver).  It may have more of those complicated features that don't work, but it is still a great unit for simple every day photo shooting.

Reviews.Title: Olympus SP-800UZ 14MP Digital Camera with 30x Wide Angle Dual Image Stabilized Zoom and 3.0 inch LCD
Reviews.Author: Don E. Buchanan
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera mainly to take pictures of our Pomeranian puppies we have for sale...The pictures come out very clear and are always in focus, I cannot say that for my Nikon D70...It functions as stated the only draw back is it doesn't have a external flash bar attachment, but if you don't need one the built in flash works just fine...I have taken pictures from as close as 2 inches to infinity and they are all clear and in focus...I would definitely recommend this camera...

Reviews.Title: Olympus Camera
Reviews.Author: Copter
Reviews.Content: I got this camera as a replacement for my Canon dSLR that broke. It's a lot smaller than i expected, which was actually a nice surprise. It's also a lot cooler looking than in the pictures, very shiny and has a good weight to it, not cheap plastic. It has lot's of cool settings, but the pictures using these don't come out very good. It's just a point and shoot with a lot of zoom power, so don't expect anything more, but if that's all you need it's a good choice.

Reviews.Title: meh camera, promptly returned
Reviews.Author: fishy "know it all"
Reviews.Content: the zoom and stabilization is incredible on this camera, but i wasnt impressed with the picture or video quality. battery life was good for both pix and vids. i knew it had a stationary lcd when i bought it, but it was a bigger issue then i thought it would be

Reviews.Title: Pretty Happy With It...
Reviews.Author: Renee
